triples.statement: In 2013, Steam was the largest digital distribution platform for PC games, holding an estimated 75% of the market share according to IHS Screen Digest.
According to Steam Spy, game purchases on Steam reached approximately US$4.3 billion by 2017, representing at least 18% of global PC game sales.
By 2021, Steam featured over 34,000 games and had more than 132 million monthly active users.
In the early 2000s, Valve sought a better method for updating its games because downloadable patches for multiplayer games caused users to disconnect for days.
Valve's proposals to companies like Microsoft, Yahoo!, and RealNetworks to build the client were rejected.
The Steam platform was announced and released for beta testing at the Game Developers Conference on March 22, 2002.
Before Steam, a 2001 publishing contract with Sierra Studios granted Valve rights for digital distribution of its games.
Sierra filed a countersuit, claiming Valve violated their contract by creating a digital storefront that competed with Sierra.
Steam was officially released from its beta phase on September 12, 2003.

Users experienced issues playing the game, partly due to legal disputes with Vivendi, which argued that the physical copies it published could not be activated because the game was not officially released from their perspective.
The requirement to use Steam raised concerns about software ownership and server overload, similar to issues seen with the Counter-Strike rollout.
In 2005, third-party developers began releasing games like Rag Doll Kung Fu and Darwinia on Steam.
In May 2007, ATI bundled Steam with its Catalyst GPU driver and provided free copies of Half-Life 2: Lost Coast and Half-Life 2: Deathmatch to ATI Radeon owners.
In January 2008, Nvidia promoted Steam in its GeForce GPU driver and offered a free copy of Portal: The First Slice to its hardware owners.
These games were subsequently released on the Origin service.
In May 2019, Microsoft began distributing its games on Steam as well as on the Microsoft Store.
In 2020, Electronic Arts began publishing some games on Steam and made its subscription service, EA Play, available on the platform.
Ubisoft announced in 2022 that it would resume selling recent games on Steam, starting with Assassin's Creed Valhalla, as part of an effort to reach different audiences.
By 2014, Steam's total annual game sales were estimated to be $1.5 billion.
The service had more than 90 million monthly active users by 2018.
In 2018, Steam's network delivered 15 billion gigabytes of data, up from less than 4 billion in 2014.

Initially, Valve had to be the publisher for games on Steam, but the introduction of the Steamworks SDK in May 2008 allowed any developer to integrate Steam into their game without Valve's direct involvement.

In March 2009, Valve updated the Steamworks SDK to include "Custom Executable Generation" (CEG), which creates a unique, encrypted game executable for each user, permitting multiple installations and software backups.
Authentication is typically done online, but after logging in once, a user can set Steam to an offline mode to play games without an internet connection.
Developers are not restricted to Steam's CEG and can use other DRM or authentication services, such as Ubisoft's Uplay service.
Valve introduced Steam Cloud in September 2008, a service that automatically stores saved games and custom files on its servers, accessible from any machine with the Steam client.
Users have the option to disable the Steam Cloud feature for individual games or for their entire account.
In May 2012, Steam enabled users to manage their game libraries from remote clients like computers and mobile devices.
Product keys purchased from third-party retailers can be redeemed on Steam.
Steam provides a framework for selling and distributing downloadable content (DLC) for games.
If the primary owner starts a game that a shared account is using, the shared user is given a few minutes to save and quit or to purchase the game for themselves.
Family View, introduced in January 2014, allows parents to adjust settings for their children's accounts, limiting access to the Steam client and games.

An enhanced version of Family Sharing called "Steam Families" was launched in September 2024, allowing up to six users to share games, play different titles simultaneously with separate saves, and use improved parental controls.
Under its acceptable use policy, Valve can block customer access to games and services if its anti-cheat software detects cheating, account selling, or exploitation of regional price differences.
Initially, this blocking policy removed access to all of a user's games, which sometimes resulted in high-value accounts being lost due to minor infractions.
Valve later changed its policy to be similar to EA's Origin, where blocked users can still access their games but are restricted to offline mode and cannot use Steam Community features.
Customers can also lose access to their games and Steam account if they do not accept changes to the end-user license agreement, with the last such instance occurring in August 2012.
Starting in April 2015, Valve enabled developers to issue player bans for their games that are enforced at the Steam level, allowing for customized community policing.
Steam delivers content from a global server network using a proprietary file transfer protocol.
Steam products are sold in various currencies based on the user's location.
The Steam storefront started supporting WebMoney payments in December 2010 and supported Bitcoin from April 2016 to December 2017, later dropping it due to value fluctuations and high fees.
Official support for Vietnamese and Latin American Spanish was added in October 2018, in addition to the 26 languages Steam already supported.
In February 2015, Steam extended the option for in-game item purchases to third-party games.
Achievements, similar to those on the Xbox 360, were added to Steam in November 2007.
Steam typically offers a wide range of discounted games during its annual Summer and Holiday sales, which often include gamification elements.
This inventory-based gifting system facilitated a gray market, allowing users in low-price regions to stockpile and resell games to users in high-price regions.
Valve updated its gifting policy in August 2016 to require immediate gifting for VAC and Game Ban-enabled games to counter ban evasion, and extended this policy to all games in May 2017.
The policy changes also restricted gifting between users in different countries when there is a significant price difference.

In November 2023, due to high inflation, Valve replaced local currency pricing in Argentina and Turkey with a U.S. dollar-based regional model, resulting in significant price increases for local users.
A grey market for Steam keys involves buyers purchasing keys in bulk at a low cost and reselling them at a higher price on third-party sites.
Some third-party sites, like G2A, have become involved in this grey market.
Publishers can request that Valve track and cancel specific keys, which removes the associated product from user libraries.
To deter mass purchases, legitimate storefronts such as Humble Bundle have implemented a minimum price for obtaining Steam keys.
Valve started limiting the frequency of region changes for Steam users in June 2021 to stop them from buying games for cheaper prices from other regions.
Steam aggregates user reviews, allowing customers to sort products based on this feedback.
In May 2016, Steam began displaying separate review aggregations for all-time reviews and those from the last 30 days to reflect changes from game updates.
In September 2016, to combat review system abuse, Valve stopped including reviews from users who activated a game via a product key in the overall score, although the reviews are still visible.
Valve also stated it would terminate business relationships with any developers or publishers found to be abusing the review system.

In March 2019, Valve announced it would mark "off-topic" review bomb reviews and exclude them from summary scores, first applying this to the Borderlands series after the announcement of Borderlands 3's timed exclusivity on the Epic Games Store.
In August 2025, Valve introduced the capability to filter game reviews by language.
In June 2011, Valve added support for free-to-play games and microtransactions via Steamworks, followed by support for trading in-game items and unopened gifts in September 2011.
Developers and publishers can give Steam Coupons to users, who can then trade them with friends like gifts or in-game items.
GameStop started selling Steam Wallet cards in May 2015.
Full Steam Market support for other games was anticipated in early 2013.
Valve introduced support for subscription-based games in April 2013, with Darkfall Unholy Wars being the first to use the service.
Steam began selling non-gaming applications in October 2012, using the same sales model as games.
Creative and productivity apps on Steam can use the Steamworks API for simplified installation, updates, and features like cloud saving and Steam Workshop.
Steam allows the purchase of game soundtracks, which can be played through Steam Music or other media players.
In 2020, Valve changed its policy on soundtracks, no longer requiring them to be DLC, which allows users to buy them without owning the game and publishers to sell soundtracks for non-Steam games.
Valve enabled publishers to rent and sell digital movies on Steam, starting primarily with video game documentaries.
After Warner Bros. offered the Mad Max films in September 2015, Lionsgate partnered with Valve in April 2016 to rent over 100 of its feature films on Steam.
Crunchyroll began offering anime for purchase or rent on Steam in March 2017.
By February 2019, Valve removed non-gaming related video content from its storefront.
Users were once able to purchase Steam Machine-related hardware through the platform.
Until October 2018, Valve took a 30% revenue share, after which it was reduced to 25% for revenues over $10 million and 20% for revenues over $50 million.
Journalists viewed the revenue policy change as an attempt to retain large developers, but it received criticism from smaller developers whose revenue share was unaffected.
In 2019, Valve collaborated with Geoff Keighley and The Game Awards to host the Steam Game Festival, a week-long event featuring numerous game demos and sales.
The event, now called the Steam Next Fest, is held several times a year, usually alongside game expositions or award shows.
In July 2024, Valve enhanced support for game demos by giving them dedicated store pages with user reviews and simplifying demo management in user libraries.
Steam Points can be exchanged in a dedicated storefront for cosmetic items for a user's profile and chat interface.
In March 2011, Valve introduced Steam Guard to protect users from account hijacking through phishing, which was a major security issue for the company.
Third-party developers can access support APIs for Steam Guard via Steamworks.

Steam Guard provides two-factor, risk-based authentication using a one-time code sent to a user's email, which was later enhanced to include two-factor authentication via the Steam mobile app's Steam Guard Mobile Authenticator.
Valve reported in 2015 that hackers were targeting user accounts to gain financial benefit from the monetary value of virtual goods.
To enhance security, Valve announced new restrictions starting in March 2016, including a 15-day hold on traded items for users who do not use the Steam Guard Mobile Authenticator.

In July 2016, following a gambling controversy related to Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, Valve announced it would take action against third-party websites that used Steam inventory trading for skin gambling.
In October 2012, research firm ReVuln published a paper identifying a security risk in the Steam browser protocol, where a user clicking a malicious `steam://` URL could trigger exploits.
This vulnerability was the second major security issue found in gaming-related software, after a problem with Ubisoft's Uplay service.

The German IT platform Heise online advised users to strictly separate gaming activities from sensitive data, suggesting methods like using a dedicated gaming PC, a separate Windows installation, or a limited-rights user account for gaming.
A software bug in July 2015 enabled anyone to reset the password for any account via the client's "forgot password" feature.
As a result of the July 2015 password reset bug, high-profile professional gamers and streamers lost access to their accounts.
In December 2015, a misconfiguration of Steam's content delivery network during a DDoS attack led to the temporary exposure of personal information on cached store pages for 34,000 users.
In May 2018, Valve launched a HackerOne bug bounty program to crowdsource the testing and improvement of the Steam client's security.
In an April 2020 report, the Anti-Defamation League stated that the Steam Community platform contained hateful content.
In February 2025, another Steam game had also distributed malware.
Since November 2013, Steam has allowed users to review their purchased games, organize them into user-defined categories, and add them to favorite lists.
Valve sponsors and distributes some modifications for free, and modifications using Steamworks can utilize any Steam features supported by their parent game.

For most games launched from Steam, the client offers an in-game overlay that allows users to access Steam Community lists, chat, manage settings, and use a built-in web browser without leaving the game.
Beginning in February 2011 as a beta, the Steam overlay allowed players to take in-game screenshots.
On February 24, 2011, the screenshot feature was fully released, allowing users to share screenshots directly to Facebook, Twitter, and Reddit from the screenshot manager.
Since 2007, Steam store game pages have displayed a score from Metacritic.
Steam's "Big Picture" mode was announced in 2011, with public betas starting in September 2012 and full integration in December 2012.
Gabe Newell described Big Picture mode as a step toward creating a dedicated Steam entertainment hardware unit.
Following the Steam Deck's introduction, Valve released a new Big Picture mode based on the Steam Deck UI, which entered beta in October 2022 and had its full release in February 2023.
The new user interface was adopted by SteamVR in October 2023.
In-Home Streaming, introduced in May 2014, enables users to stream games with low latency from one computer to another on the same home network.
In June 2019, Valve renamed the feature to Remote Play and expanded it to allow game streaming to devices outside the user's home network.
"Remote Play Together," added in November 2019 after beta testing, allows local multiplayer games to be played by users in different locations, although it may not solve inherent latency issues.
In February 2021, Remote Play Together was updated to allow non-Steam users to be invited to play via the Steam Link app.
The Steam client functions as a social network service, allowing users to add friends and join groups through the Steam Community feature.
Each user has a personal page displaying their groups, friends, game library, achievements, and wishlists, with an option to keep this information private.
Valve reported in January 2010 that 10 million out of 25 million active Steam accounts were registered with the Steam Community.
During the 2012 Steam Summer Sale, user profiles were updated to include Badges that show a user's participation in the community and past events.
Players can trade these cards on the Steam Community Marketplace or craft them into "Badges" to receive rewards like discount coupons and profile customization options.
In 2010, the Steam client began acting as an OpenID provider, enabling third-party websites to authenticate a user's Steam identity without accessing their credentials.
To prevent abuse, access to most community features is restricted until a user makes a one-time payment of at least US$5 to Valve.
Steamworks includes Valve Anti-Cheat (VAC), which allows game servers to automatically detect and report users who are cheating in online multiplayer games.
In August 2012, Valve updated the Community area with new features, such as dedicated game hub pages that showcase top user-created content, forum posts, and screenshots.
A feature allowing users to upload game strategy guides and walkthroughs was added in December 2012.
Beginning in January 2015, the Steam client enabled players to livestream their gameplay to friends or the public.
For The International 2018 Dota 2 tournament, Valve launched Steam.tv as a significant update to Steam Broadcasting, incorporating Steam Chat and Steamworks for watching matches.
Steam.tv has also been utilized for other events, including a pre-release tournament for the game Artifact, The Game Awards 2018, and the Steam Awards.
A Game Recording feature, which allows for on-demand or background recording of gameplay, was added in beta in June 2024 and fully released by November 2024.
Steam Music was added to the client in September 2014, enabling users to play local music files or stream music from another computer on the same network.
In July 2018, the friends and chat system was updated with non-peer-to-peer chats, integrated voice chat, and other features comparable to Discord.
A standalone mobile app for Android and iOS based on the updated chat system was released in May 2019.

A major visual overhaul of the Steam Library was released in October 2019 to help users organize games, see what friends are playing, view live-streams, discover new content, and provide more sorting options.
A visual and architectural overhaul released in June 2023 unified the backend for the Steam and Steam Deck clients and redesigned the desktop client.
Valve allows developers to create storefront pages to generate interest in their games before release.
Setting a release date is necessary for Valve's "build review," a free service conducted about a week before a game's launch to ensure it is trouble-free.
In 2020, updates to Discovery queues provided developers with more options for customizing their storefront pages and integrating them with the Steam client.
Valve provides a free application programming interface (API) called Steamworks, which offers development and publishing tools to game and software developers.
The Steamworks API also includes anti-cheating tools and digital copy management.
In 2016, the Steamworks API was updated to include a generic controller library for developers, enabling customization features for third-party controllers, starting with the DualShock 4.

Steam's Input API has been updated to officially support various console controllers, including the Nintendo Switch Pro Controller in 2018, and the Xbox Wireless Controller and PlayStation 5's DualSense in 2020.
Valve stated in November 2020 that controller usage had more than doubled over the previous two years.
In February 2014, Valve began allowing developers to create their own sales for their games, independent of sales set by Valve.
Valve may collaborate with developers to suggest their participation in themed sales events.
Since 2007, Steam has conducted and partially published a monthly, opt-in hardware survey.
In 2010, Steam began collecting data on installed software.
Early access serves as a way for developers to receive funding to help complete their games.
The early access model enabled more developers to publish on Steam without direct curation from Valve, which significantly increased the number of games on the service.
In 2020, Valve introduced Steam Playtest, which allows developers to conduct closed beta tests for their games before a public release.
While Valve typically honors all requests for Steam keys, it will evaluate some to prevent the distribution of keys for games or offerings designed to manipulate the Steam storefront.
In June 2021, Valve made it possible for multiple developers to collaborate on creating game bundles.
Originally used for distributing in-game items for Team Fortress 2, the Workshop was redesigned in early 2012 to support any game, including mods for The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
A May 2012 patch for Portal 2 added the ability to share user-created levels via a new map-making tool integrated with the Workshop.
Independently developed games like Dungeons of Dredmor can also use the Workshop to support user-made content.
In June 2012, Dota 2 became Valve's third game to support the Workshop, allowing for customizable accessories, character skins, and announcer packs.

Workshop content can be monetized, a concept inspired by World of Warcraft's gold farming, which aimed to incentivize players and content creators and informed Valve's approach to Team Fortress 2 and other multiplayer games.
By January 2015, Valve had integrated some user-developed Workshop content as paid features in its own games like Team Fortress 2 and Dota 2, paying over $57 million to content creators.
In January 2015, Valve started allowing developers to use advanced monetization features where profits are shared with content creators; this went live in April 2015, beginning with mods for Skyrim.
The paid mod feature was removed a few days later due to negative user feedback and issues with pricing and copyright misuse.
Six months after removing the paid mod feature, Valve expressed continued interest in offering similar functionality in the future.
The Steam client was updated in November 2015 to allow developers to sell in-game items directly through the store, with Rust being the first game to implement this feature.

SteamVR is a virtual reality hardware and software platform from Valve that focuses on "room-scale" experiences using positional tracking base stations, rather than requiring the player to stay in one location.
Originally available for Windows, macOS, and Linux, Valve discontinued macOS support for SteamVR in May 2020.
SteamVR 2.0, released in October 2023, introduced a new overlay interface unified with the updated interfaces of SteamOS and Big Picture mode.
Since 2012, Valve has moved away from manual game approval to allow more games on Steam, with their validation limited to confirming that a game runs on its specified platforms.

In 2017, Steam developer Alden Kroll stated that because Valve recognizes Steam's near-monopoly on PC game sales, the company wants to avoid determining what gets sold and has sought to remove itself from the game-addition process.
Valve also acknowledged that an uncontrolled influx of games onto the service could lead to problems with discoverability and the presence of low-quality titles.
Valve announced Steam Greenlight in July 2012, releasing it the following month to streamline the process of adding games to the service.
Users pledged support for games, and Valve would then make the most-pledged games available on Steam.
Due to a flood of inappropriate or false submissions in its first week, Valve began requiring developers to pay a US$100 fee to list a game on the service.
The fees collected were donated to the charity Child's Play.
The fee caused concern among smaller developers who might not be able to afford it.
A later change allowed developers to post conceptual ideas on Greenlight for free to gauge interest, with the vote counts visible only to the developer.
Non-gaming software was also permitted to be voted onto the service via Greenlight.
Developers initially criticized the Greenlight process because, despite liking the concept, the approval rate for games was low.
In January 2013, Gabe Newell stated that Valve saw its role in Greenlight as a bottleneck and planned to eliminate it with an open marketplace infrastructure.
To demonstrate a change in direction, Valve approved 100 games at once on the eve of Greenlight's first anniversary.
Valve launched Steam Direct on June 13, 2017, one week after shutting down the Greenlight program.
After applying, developers must wait thirty days for Valve to review their game to ensure it is configured correctly, matches its store page description, and contains no malicious content.
When announcing Steam Direct, Valve suggested a fee between $100 and $5,000 to encourage serious submissions and filter out low-quality games, thereby improving the discovery process for customers.
Smaller developers expressed concern that the Direct fee could harm them and prevent good indie games from being released on the Steam store.
After considering community concerns, Valve set the Direct fee at $100 and planned to improve its discovery algorithms with more human involvement.
The fee is refunded by Valve if the game's sales exceed $1,000.
Valve expected the number of new games added to the service to increase after Steam Direct was implemented.
Groups like publisher Raw Fury and crowdfunding site Fig have offered to pay the Direct fee for indie developers who cannot afford it.
Valve sought methods to help players discover games they would likely purchase based on their previous buying habits.
Valve has used algorithms and other automated features for game discovery, which has helped unexpected hits become more visible.
The September 2014 "Discovery Update" introduced tools for Steam users to act as curators for game recommendations and added sorting functions for popular and user-specific games.
Valve deemed the Discovery update successful, reporting in March 2015 that it led to increased storefront usage and an 18% rise in sales revenue.
In November 2016, a second Discovery update was released, which gave users more control over game visibility and provided developers with improved tools for game presentation.
In 2016, an increasing number of games met a Valve-defined success metric of earning over $200,000 in revenue within their first 90 days of release.
The direct game access feature, which bypasses Steam redemption keys, is designed to reduce key reselling and prevent abuse of the curator system for obtaining free games.
To address "fake games" created with reused assets and minimal innovation, Valve introduced the Steam Explorers program.
The Steam Labs feature was launched in July 2019 as a way for Valve to test experimental discovery features and gather public feedback.
After maturing through user testing, successful Steam Labs experiments have been integrated as permanent features in the storefront.
Despite Valve's goal of improving visibility for niche games, the September 2019 Discovery update was criticized by some indie developers who observed a significant decrease in their games' exposure.
Introduced in September 2022, Steam Charts publicly track the platform's top-selling and most-played games, with historical data available weekly and monthly.
In June 2015, Valve established a formal refund process, guaranteeing refunds within the first two weeks for games played for less than two hours.
Before June 2015, Valve had a no-refunds policy but would grant them in specific situations like DRM issues or false advertising.
Games that are no longer for sale can still be downloaded and played by users who had previously purchased them.
Beginning in June 2018, Valve took action against "trolling" games and developers, and in September 2018, defined trolls as those not making good faith efforts to create and sell games.
Valve's Lombardi cited the game Active Shooter as an example of trolling, describing it as being "designed to do nothing but generate outrage and cause conflict through its existence."
Valve removed approximately 170 games from Steam within one month of clarifying its definition of trolling.
Valve has taken steps to mitigate the impact of "fake games" used to manipulate the trading card market or boost user Steam levels, and has implemented changes to prevent such abuse.
Some of these changes led to false positives, such as the game Wandersong being flagged in January 2019, which the developer believed was due to its nearly unanimous positive user reviews.
Valve has removed games from developers for other policy violations, including asset flips, review manipulation, misuse of Steamworks tools, and hostile actions toward users.
Since 2022, Valve has banned games that use blockchain technologies like non-fungible tokens (NFTs) due to the questionable nature of their markets.
In 2023, as generative AI became more prevalent, Valve initially permitted games with AI-generated content on Steam, but warned developers to ensure they held the rights to that content.

Amid growing copyright and ethical concerns in late 2023, Valve updated its policy in January 2024 to require developers to disclose the use of generative AI on their game's store page and explain how they ensured the AI did not create illegal content.
In February, Valve updated its policies to ban games that integrated paid advertising into the gameplay loop, such as watching an ad for virtual rewards.

Valve continues to use the Steam Hardware Survey to collect hardware distribution information, sharing the results with other developers to understand the market and decide when to discontinue support for older hardware and software.
Steam was first released exclusively for Microsoft Windows in 2003 and was later ported to other platforms.
More recent versions of the Steam client use the Chromium Embedded Framework.
When support for Windows XP and Vista was dropped, approximately 0.2% of Steam users were affected.
In March 2023, Valve announced that Steam would end support for Windows 7 and 8 on January 1, 2024.
Valve announced a client for macOS in March 2010.
Before the announcement, the Steam beta client was changed to support the WebKit rendering engine instead of Internet Explorer's Trident engine.
To tease the release, Valve sent images to Mac community and gaming websites featuring Valve game characters with Apple logos and parodies of old Macintosh ads.

To announce the availability of Half-Life 2 on the service, Valve created a video homage to Apple's "1984" Macintosh commercial, using some concept images that had previously been used to tease the Mac Steam client.
Along with the Steam client, developers were given features to utilize the cross-platform Source engine and Steamworks' capabilities.
The Steam Play feature on the macOS client enables players who bought compatible games on Windows to download the Mac versions for free.
Steam Cloud and many multiplayer PC games support cross-platform play.

Following Apple's decision to discontinue support for Intel-based Macs after macOS Tahoe's release in late 2025, Valve updated the Steam client beta to natively support Apple silicon without requiring Rosetta 2 emulation.
In July 2012, Valve announced it was developing a Steam client for Linux based on the Ubuntu distribution.
The announcement came after months of speculation, mainly from the website Phoronix, which had found evidence of Linux development in recent builds of Steam and other Valve games.
Gabe Newell identified getting Steam and games running on Linux as a key strategy for Valve, describing Microsoft Windows 8 as "a catastrophe" for the PC space and praising Linux for its openness.
According to Gabe Newell, Valve is supporting developers who wish to bring their games to Linux by making the process as easy as possible.
The team developing the Linux client had worked for a year before the announcement to confirm that a port was feasible.
By the time of the official announcement, a nearly feature-complete Steam client for Linux had been developed and was running successfully on Ubuntu.
Internal beta testing of the Linux client began in October 2012, with external beta testing following in early November of the same year.
Open beta clients for Linux were released in late December 2012, and the official client was released in mid-February 2013.
After that, Valve started porting other games to Ubuntu and expanding to additional Linux distributions.
By October 2013, versions of Steam were released for Fedora and Red Hat Enterprise Linux.
Proton enables the use of Steam-supported controllers, including those that are not compatible with Windows.
Valve's handheld computer, the Steam Deck, was released in February 2022 and runs on SteamOS 3.0 (based on Arch Linux), using Proton to support Windows games that lack native Linux versions.
This effort included working with anti-cheat developers like Easy Anti-Cheat and BattlEye to ensure their software worked with Proton.
To aid compatibility, Valve created a classification system to rate games based on their out-of-the-box performance on the Steam Deck.
In June 2021, Proton added support for Nvidia's DLSS on compatible video cards and games, although this feature is unavailable on the AMD-based Steam Deck.
Google offered a prerelease version of Steam on Chromebooks in March 2022, which entered public beta in November 2022.
Google announced in August 2025 that it will terminate support for Steam on Chromebooks in 2026.
At E3 2010, Gabe Newell announced that Steamworks would arrive on the PlayStation 3 with the game Portal 2.
Features offered included cross-platform play, instant messaging, Steam Cloud for saved games, and the option for PlayStation 3 owners to download Portal 2 from Steam for Windows and Mac.
Valve's Counter-Strike: Global Offensive also supports Steamworks and cross-platform features on the PlayStation 3, including the use of keyboard and mouse controls as an alternative to a gamepad.
Valve expressed hope to expand on this foundation with more Steam features and functionality in DLC and future content releases.

Gabe Newell stated that Valve wanted to bring Steamworks to the Xbox 360 via Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, but later confirmed that cross-platform play would not be in the final version of the game.
Valve's Erik Johnson said that Microsoft's requirement for new content to be certified and validated before distribution would limit the utility of the Steamworks delivery method.
Valve released an official Steam client for iOS and Android devices in late January 2012 after a short beta period.
Gabe Newell stated that the application was a strong request from Steam users and a way to make Steam "richer and more accessible for everyone".
A mobile Steam client for Windows Phone devices was released in June 2016.
In May 2019, a mobile chat-only client for Steam named Steam Chat was released.
On May 14, 2018, a beta version of the "Steam Link" app was released, allowing users to stream games to Android phones.
The Steam Link app was submitted to the iOS App Store but was denied by Apple, who cited "business conflicts with app guidelines".
At a subsequent Apple Worldwide Developers Conference, Apple clarified that iOS apps cannot offer an app-like purchasing store but are not restricted from providing remote desktop support.
In response, Valve removed the purchasing feature from the app, resubmitted it in June 2018, and it was accepted by Apple and released on their store in May 2019.
The gaming community preemptively called these potential devices "Steam Boxes," expecting them to be dedicated machines similar to traditional video game consoles.
In September 2013, Valve revealed SteamOS, a custom Linux-based operating system, and the final concept for the Steam Machine hardware.
Unlike other consoles, the Steam Machine did not have set hardware; its technology was implemented by the manufacturer and was fully customizable, similar to a personal computer.
In 2018, Steam Machines were removed from the storefront due to low sales and minimal user traffic.
In November 2015, Valve released the Steam Link set-top box and the Steam Controller, the latter of which was discontinued in 2019.
The Steam Link hardware was discontinued in 2018, and the name now refers to the Remote Play mobile app for streaming PC content to a mobile device.
Valve released the Steam Deck, a handheld gaming computer running an updated version of SteamOS, with initial shipments beginning on February 25, 2022.
The Steam Deck is designed to play Steam games and can be connected to an external display via a separate dock.
The Steam Deck was released on February 25, 2022.
Valve started a Steam Deck Validated program to mark games on its service according to their compatibility with the Steam Deck software.

Initially, Steam Cloud Play was exclusively available through Nvidia's GeForce Now service, with plans to integrate other cloud services later, although it was uncertain if Valve would operate its own service.

By November 2017, over half of Steam's userbase was fluent in Chinese due to the popularity of Dota 2 and PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds in China, and some developers reported that Chinese players accounted for nearly 30% of their games' total player base.

After a temporary block of many Steam functions by the Chinese government in December 2017, Valve and Perfect World announced a partnership to create an official version of Steam compliant with Chinese internet regulations.
Perfect World had previously collaborated with Valve to release Dota 2 and Counter-Strike: Global Offensive in China through official government approval processes.
Games released on Steam China must undergo government approval and meet requirements like having a Chinese company operate any online game.
Steam China was created to comply with China's strict video game regulations.
Valve does not intend to block Chinese users from the global Steam platform and aims to ensure player cloud data is compatible between both versions.
The Steam China client launched in open beta on February 9, 2021, with approximately 40 games.
By December 2021, Steam China offered only about 100 government-reviewed and licensed games.
The block effectively prevented all Chinese users from accessing games they had bought on Steam's international service.
In 2023, it was reported that the Steam Store was accessible as normal in China, but the Steam Community remained blocked.
Steam has faced criticism for its support of DRM and for being an effective monopoly.
In March 2015, the Better Business Bureau gave Valve a failing "F" grade due to numerous complaints about Steam, prompting Valve's Erik Johnson to admit their customer service was inadequate.
Johnson said that Valve planned to improve customer support by integrating features into the Steam client and increasing responsiveness.
At that time, Valve stated that 98% of all service requests were processed within 24 hours of being filed.
Gabe Newell described Valve as "tremendously profitable," with higher profitability per employee than companies like Google or Apple.
By August 2017, Steam had added 27 million new active accounts since January 2016, reaching a total of at least 150 million active users.
While most Steam accounts were from North America and Western Europe, there was significant growth in Asian accounts around 2017 due to localization and new currency options.
The number of Australian Steam accounts grew from 1.4 million in September 2014 to 2.2 million by October 2015.
By August 2017, Valve reported a peak of 14 million concurrent players (up from 8.4 million in 2015), with 33 million daily active users and 67 million monthly active users.
The peak concurrent user count on Steam reached 18.5 million by January 2018, with daily active users exceeding 47 million.
In March 2020, during the COVID-19 pandemic, Steam's concurrent player count exceeded 23 million.

The concurrent player count on Steam reached 39.2 million by December 2024, driven by releases like Marvel Rivals and Path of Exile 2, and grew to 40 million by February 2025 with the release of Monster Hunter Wilds.
Steam's all-time concurrent user peak hit 41.6 million in October 2025, a surge largely attributed to the release of Battlefield 6.
An analysis by Alinea Analytics estimated Steam's revenue for the first 11 months of 2025 to be $16.3 billion.
The largest spikes in the sales graph for Garry's Mod are caused by sales and promotions.
By April 2014, Garry's Mod had sold nearly five million copies through Steam.
A chart shows the number of new games published on Steam by year, as estimated by Steam Spy in January 2020.
Steam's library grew from seven games in 2004 to over 30,000 by 2019, with an additional 20,000 non-gaming products.
As of February 2021, there were more than 50,000 games on Steam.

The growth in the number of games on Steam is attributed to changes in Valve's curation approach, allowing publishers to add games without direct involvement, and the support for virtual reality games.
The addition of Greenlight and Direct accelerated the number of games on Steam, with nearly 40% of the 19,000 games available at the end of 2017 having been released that year.
The number of new games published per week expanded to about seventy with Greenlight, and doubled to one hundred and eighty after the introduction of Direct.
In 2011, Valve's Jason Holtman said the company believed public sales data was outdated for a digital market.
Data provided by Valve to developers cannot be released without permission due to a non-disclosure agreement.
In 2015, the website Steam Spy was created, using algorithms on public user profile data to estimate game sales.
The privacy setting change broke Steam Spy's data collection method, making it unusable.
Some asserted Valve used the GDPR change to block sales estimation methods, though Valve later promised to provide more accurate tools for developers.
In 2020, Simon Carless revised an earlier method to estimate sales based on the number of Steam reviews, using a modified "Boxleiter number" as a multiplication factor.
In September 2014, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) sued Valve for violating Australian consumer laws by not having a formal refund policy for faulty products.
The ACCC won its lawsuit in March 2016, while acknowledging that Valve had changed its policy during the legal proceedings.
In December 2016, a court fined Valve A$3 million and required it to add language to Steam outlining the rights of Australian consumers.
Valve's request to appeal the decision to the High Court of Australia in January 2018 was dismissed.
In September 2018, Valve was fined 147,000 and ordered to change its refund policy after it was found to violate French consumer laws.

The French consumer group UFC-Que Choisir sued Valve in December 2015 over Steam policies that conflicted with French law, including the restriction on reselling purchased games, a practice that is legal in the European Union.
In September 2019, a Paris court ruled that Valve's policy of preventing game resales violated EU directives and ordered the company to permit it in the future.

The Interactive Software Federation of Europe (ISFE) stated that the French court's ruling contradicted established EU case law on digital copies and could disrupt digital distribution systems in Europe if upheld.
In August 2016, BT Group sued Valve, alleging that the Steam client's Library, Chat, Messaging, and Broadcasting services infringed on four of its patents.
These practices were considered to be against the European Union's Digital Single Market initiative.
The French gaming trade group, Syndicat National du Jeu Vido, stated that geo-blocking was a necessary tool to prevent improper reselling of product keys.
In January 2021, the Commission found that Valve and its co-defendants had violated EU antitrust rules, issued combined fines of 7.8 million, and could face further lawsuits from consumers.
Valve chose not to cooperate and received the largest fine of 1.6 million among the defendants.
A class-action lawsuit in January 2021 alleged that Valve's "most favored nation" pricing contract, which required developers to maintain price parity with other platforms, stifled competition.
Simon Carless of Gamasutra analyzed the lawsuit, suggesting it might lack merit because Valve's terms apply only to the resale of Steam keys, not the games themselves.
In April 2021, Wolfire Games filed a separate class-action lawsuit asserting that Steam is a monopoly and that its 30% revenue cut and "most favored nation" pricing practices violate antitrust laws.
Valve defended its 30% revenue cut as being the industry standard and argued that Wolfire's claim about Steam's market share lacked evidence.
In November 2021, a judge dismissed Wolfire's lawsuit, ruling that the company had not proven Valve held a monopoly on game sales and noting the 30% cut had been consistent.
Wolfire refiled its case with a narrower complaint focusing on Valve's alleged use of its dominance to intimidate developers, which a judge allowed to proceed in May 2022.
During the discovery phase, Valve was ordered to have Gabe Newell give a deposition regarding Steam's business strategy.
On November 26, 2024, a class of game sellers allegedly harmed by Valve's policies was certified, with the case expected to go to trial.
In September 2024, Valve updated Steam's terms of service to remove the forced arbitration clause, allowing disputes and class-action lawsuits to be resolved in court.
